tasks: Create a simple wireframe of a login page using the 8-point grid system, focusing on proper alignment and spacing. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system) Score improvement: +5% in UI Craft & Visual Design
Write down 3 common UX mistakes you've seen in designs and explain how to avoid them using Tesler's Law. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/teslers-law/) Score improvement: +10% in UX Fundamentals

Conduct a user interview and document 5 pain points using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework. (Reference: https://nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/) Score improvement: +15% in User Research & Validation

Create a list of 10 UX principles you'd like to learn more about, along with their definitions and examples. Focus on Hick's Law and Aesthetic-Usability Effect. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/hicks-law/ and https://lawsofux.com/aesthetic-usability-effect/) Score improvement: +20% in UX Fundamentals

Design a simple prototype of a product feature using Figma or Sketch, focusing on error states you missed. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system) Score improvement: +25% in UI Craft & Visual Design

Write a short essay (max 500 words) explaining the concept of Hick's Law and how it applies to your design work. Include examples from your own projects or research. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/hicks-law/) Score improvement: +30% in UX Fundamentals

Create a comprehensive guide for designers on how to apply Hick's Law and Aesthetic-Usability Effect in their work. Include examples, best practices, and potential pitfalls. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/hicks-law/ and https://lawsofux.com/aesthetic-usability-effect/) Score improvement: +40% in UX Fundamentals

Design a case study of a product redesign that successfully applied the principles learned throughout this 4-week journey. Include before-and-after comparisons, user research findings, and design decisions. (Reference: https://nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/) Score improvement: +50% in Product Thinking & Strategy

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, your role is to uncover new insights and possibilities that shape the future of products. To excel in this position, focus on developing a strong foundation in UX Fundamentals, leveraging your UI Craft & Visual Design skills to create intuitive experiences, conducting thorough user research and validation to inform design decisions, and collaborating effectively with cross-functional teams to drive product strategy and growth.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Hick's Law for Efficient Navigation
topics.summary: Applying Hick's Law to design intuitive navigation can improve user experience.
practice_points: Create a usability test script to evaluate the impact of response time on navigation decisions
Analyze 3 existing websites and identify areas where Hick's Law is applied (or not)
Design an interactive prototype with varying response times to demonstrate the law's effect

topics.name: Developing a Personal Style Guide for UI Craft & Visual Design
topics.summary: Establishing a consistent visual language enhances user engagement and brand recognition.
practice_points: Create a mood board with 5 color palettes inspired by nature and design principles
Design 3 UI components (button, input field, header) using the Aesthetic-Usability Effect framework
Develop a typography guide with font pairing suggestions for 2-3 different screen sizes

topics.name: Conducting User Research with the Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
topics.summary: Understanding users' motivations and goals improves product design and user satisfaction.
practice_points: Recruit 2 participants to share their jobs-to-be-done for a specific task (e.g., grocery shopping)
Conduct 2 interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework and document findings
Create a personas document with job descriptions, goals, and pain points
